title: Watermen of Reedville and the Chesapeake Bay (Images of America)
features: The story of Reedville, Virginia, is linked to the commercial fishing industry that developed in the late 19th century. In 1874, Elijah Reed transferred his menhaden fishing operation from Brooklin, Maine, to the Chesapeake Bay. He purchased the land on Cockrell's Creek that is now Reedville. The industry flourished, especially in the early part of the 20th century. Today, Reedville is one of the major ports for the landing of commercial fish in the United States, second only to Kodiak, Alaska. This Northern Neck area of Virginia has a deep history dating back to Jamestown, and this book adds another chapter in retelling its past by providing unique photographs that have never been previously published.
description: Shawn Hall is the executive director of the Reedville Fishermen's Museum. He graduated from Harvard in 1983 and received his master's degree from California State University in 1988. Shawn has authored eight books about the Silver State, including Ghost Towns and Mining Camps of Southern Nevada as part of Arcadia's Images of America series. All royalties from the sale of this book will be donated to the Reedville Fishermen's Museum.

author: {'avatar': 'https://m.media-amazon.com/images/S/amzn-author-media-prod/lv6ejgvp5bbrcaouvacpre3rc7._SY600_.jpg', 'name': 'Shawn Hall', 'about': ['Born and raised in Massachusetts, Shawn caught the Ghost Town Fever in high school. While attending Harvard, he made his first trip to Nye County and his first book was published in 1981. He came back to Nevada every year during the summer to explore new territory for future books and also cowboy on a central Nevada ranch. After graduation in 1983, he moved permanently to Nevada and has continued writing while pursuing a career running a number of Nevada museums. 8 books later, he is finishing up his next project on Esmeralda and Mineral counties, hopefully to be finished in 2022. He has dedicated his life to helping preserving and documenting the history of these wonderful Nevada ghost towns for future generations. Remember, take photographs and nothing else! Please leave these beautiful and historic towns as they are and treat them with the respect they deserve.']}
